required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Intramuscular Ketorolac Versus Oral Ibuprofen for Pain Relief in First Trimester Suction Curettage
clinical_study.official_title: Intramuscular Ketorolac Versus Oral Ibuprofen for Pain Relief in First Trimester Suction Curettage: a Randomized Clinical Trial.

brief_summary.textblock:
The aim of this study is to compare the effect of pre-procedural ketorolac to ibuprofen on immediate post-procedural pain scores in patients undergoing first trimester suction curettage with local anesthesia only.
Our primary hypothesis is that IM ketorolac compared to oral ibuprofen will result in an approximate 30% reduction in pain scores on a 21-point numerical rating scale immediately after the procedure.
Secondary hypotheses include:
- Pain scores on the 21-point scale will also be significantly lower in the ketorolac group immediately after cervical dilation and 15 minutes post-procedure.
- Fewer patients in the ketorolac group will rate their pain as "severe" on a subjective pain rating scale.
- Patients in the ketorolac group will be more satisfied with their pain control.
- Side effects will be similar between groups.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately (within 1 minute) after suction and speculum removal
primary_outcome.description: The primary endpoint is subjects' immediate post-procedure pain score on a 21-point 0 to 100 scale, 0 = no pain and 100 = worst possible pain (in increments of five). This scale has been previously validated and used for research purposes, including for pain research evaluating suction curettage elsewhere and at our institution (Jensen 1986, Williamson 2004, Allen 2009).

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain Scores Immediately After Cervical Dilation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately (within 1 minute) after cervical dilation prior to the introduction of the suction cannula
secondary_outcome.description: 21-point 0 to 100 scale where 0 = no pain and 100 = worst possible pain (in increments of five)
21-point 0 to 100 scale, where 0 = no pain and 100 = worst possible pain (in increments of five)

arm_group.description: Intramuscular injection of ketorolac 60 mg in 2cc -plus- placebo tablet (calcium carbonate 600 mg tablet). For subjects who are 50 kg or less, intramuscular injection of ketorolac 30 mg in 1cc -plus- placebo tablet (calcium carbonate 600 mg tablet)
Ibuprofen 800 mg tablet -plus- intramuscular injection of 2cc saline placebo. For subjects weighing 50 kg or less, ibuprofen 600 mg tablet -plus- intramuscular injection of 2cc saline placebo

intervention.description: For subjects weighing over 50 kg, ketorolac 60 mg in 2cc administered via intramuscular injection 30-60 minutes before suction curettage procedure. For subjects weighing 50 kg or less, ketorolac 30 mg in 1 cc administered via intramuscular injection 30-60 minutes before suction curettage procedure

For subjects weighing over 50 kg, ibuprofen 800 mg tablet administered orally 60-90 minutes before suction curettage procedure. For subjects weighing 50 kg or less, ibuprofen 600 mg tablet administered orally 60-90 minutes before suction curettage procedure.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women age 18 or older seeking suction curettage at Planned Parenthood League of Massachusetts (PPLM)
- Gestational age less than or equal to 11+6, confirmed by ultrasound
- Eligible for suction curettage according to PPLM protocols
- Choice of local anesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- Choice of IV sedation for pain control
- Hypersensitivity to NSAIDs or lidocaine
- Contraindications to NSAIDs:
Active renal disease Active hepatic disease Gastric ulcer disease or gastritis Long-term NSAID or aspirin use Bleeding disorder
- NSAIDs taken < 8 hours prior to procedure
- Need for cervical ripening with either misoprostol or mechanical priming agent (laminaria/Dilapan)
- Long-term narcotic use
- Unable or unwilling to complete required study procedures
- Previous participation in the study

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Dates of recruitment period: June 2011-May 2012 Clinic: free-standing, outpatient health center

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
